title: Dylan’s world of sports data
text: This is my sports data journalism blog. I want to show the world that I can do data journalism at a high level. It’s really important to me and makes me feel quite smart because I never thought I could do this before.

title: Big Ten Plays
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)




Code
 footballlogs_22 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs22.csv")
footballlogs_23 <- read_csv("https://dwillis.github.io/sports-data-files/footballlogs23.csv")




Code
#filtering TeamFull for the big_ten opponents.
 big_ten_logs_22 <- footballlogs_22 %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
 big_ten_logs_23 <- footballlogs_23 %>% 
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
# generateing average offensive plays for 2022

avg_offense_b10 <- big_ten_logs_22 %>% 
group_by(TeamFull) %>% 
summarize(avg_offplays_22 = mean(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
arrange(desc(avg_offplays_22))




Code
#2023 avg offensive plays 

avg_offense_b10_23 <- big_ten_logs_23 %>% 
group_by(TeamFull) %>% 
summarize(avg_offplays_23 = mean(OffensivePlays)) %>% 
arrange(desc(avg_offplays_23))




Code
#joined dataframes

avg_offensive_plays_joined <- inner_join(avg_offense_b10, avg_offense_b10_23, by = "TeamFull")

avg_offensive_plays_joined <- avg_offensive_plays_joined %>% 
mutate(difference = avg_offplays_23 - avg_offplays_22)


Purdue and Penn State are interesting in this list. Why? Because Penn State is producing 10 more offensive plays on average in 2023 than a season ago. It finished in the middle of the conference then with around 70 offensive plays per game and now sits No. 1 in the conference.
As for Purdue, it may have gotten off the most offensive plays on average but the Boilermakers ranked in the bottom half of the conference in offensive efficiency last sesaon with a rating of 128.4. Rutgers had the lowest at 99.8


Code
#plotting this on a graph
#I used ChatGPT to tell me where desc goes.

#2022 graph
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=avg_offense_b10, 
    aes(x=reorder(TeamFull, -desc(avg_offplays_22)),
        weight=avg_offplays_22)) +
  labs(
    title="Purdue isn't stuck in the middle with you",
    subtitle = "Boilermaker offense valued quantity in 2022 offense",
    caption = "Source: Sports Data Journalism Class",
    x="Team", 
    y="Average number of offensive plays") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()





This sesaon, Penn State and Purdue are a bit closer in offensive efficiency and with Purdue ranking second in the average amount of offensive plays, it shows the Boilermakers know how to manage the ball.
Their two quarterbacks Drew Allen and Hudson Card, rank No. 4 and 5, respectively in the Big Ten in passing efficiency. Allen does have a slight edge over Card in passing percentage through five games in 2023.


Code
#2023 graph
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=avg_offense_b10_23, 
    aes(x=reorder(TeamFull, -desc(avg_offplays_23)),
        weight=avg_offplays_23)) +
  labs(
    title="Penn State's offensive surging in 2023",
    subtitle = "Nittany Lions were sixth in the Big Ten last season",
    caption = "Source: Sports Data Journalism Class",
    x="Team", 
    y="Average number of offensive plays") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()

title: Volleyball aces per match
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(ggrepel)
set.seed(1234)




Code
players <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dwillis/NCAAWomensVolleyballData/main/data/ncaa_womens_volleyball_playerstats_2023.csv")




Code
# limits
players <- players %>% 
  filter(mp > 20) %>% 
  filter (!is.na(aces), !is.na(pos))




Code
#aces per match for players

acespermatch <- players %>% 
  group_by(full_name) %>% 
  mutate(acespermatch = (aces / mp)) %>% 
  arrange(desc(acespermatch))

#looking at summary
summary(acespermatch$acespermatch)
#3Q is 0.9545




Code
#aces

good_aces <- acespermatch |> filter(acespermatch > 0.9545)




Code
ggplot() + geom_beeswarm(data=good_aces, aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="grey")




Code
#maryland players

umd <- good_aces |> 
  filter(team == "Maryland Terrapins, Terps") |> 
  filter(acespermatch>0.9545) |> 
  arrange(desc(acespermatch))


Sam Csire leads Maryland in kills and her teammates aren’t too close to her. When it comes to aces per match she does have some friends. Csire is relatively close to fellow senior Lilly Gunter who averages nearly the same amount. Gunter has one more ace than Csire on the year and junior Erin Engel isn’t far behind with 22. Gunter’s five aces against Howard University were her most on the season.
In the broader NCAA, Maryland’s trio is relatively low on the list of players who play in at least 20 points per game.


Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=good_aces, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="grey") + 
  geom_beeswarm(
    data=umd, 
    groupOnX=TRUE, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch), color="red")+
  geom_text_repel(
    data=umd, 
    aes(x=pos, y=acespermatch, label=full_name))+
  labs(
     title="Some games are an A+, not all", 
     subtitle="Three Maryland players average slightly over one ace per game",
     caption = "Source: NCAA | Graphic by Dylan Manfre")

0.7.1.

title: Maryland YPP
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(cfbfastR)
library(ggrepel)




Code
# loading data

logs <- read_csv("https://thescoop.org/sports-data-files/footballlogs1123.csv")




Code
# Populating the NAs
# if the month is January its years -1 otherwise its year. Code is from chat GPT
logs <- logs %>%
 mutate(
    Season = ifelse(
      is.na(Season),
      ifelse(format(Date, "%Y") == "2022" & format(Date, "%m") == "01",
             as.integer(format(Date, "%Y")) - 1,
             as.integer(format(Date, "%Y"))
      ),
      Season
    )
  )




Code
winlosslogs <- logs |> 
  mutate(
    wins = case_when(
      grepl("W", Outcome) ~ 1, 
      grepl("L", Outcome) ~ 0)
)


Is Maryland football getting good the last few seasons? Well, 2023 has at least shown progress in that area and 2022 it was right on the money. In short, if you’re in the bottom right quadrant, you’re golden. Meaning you’re getting a lot of yards and not allowing much from your opponent.
2022 meant that Maryland was about average for the amount of yardage it gained on offense and it kept opposing teams at bay.


Code
#grouping by years
years_md <-  winlosslogs %>% 
  filter(Team == "Maryland") %>% 
  group_by(Season) %>% 
summarise(
    TotalPlays = sum(OffensivePlays), 
    TotalYards = sum(OffensiveYards), 
    DefensivePlays = sum(DefPlays), 
    DefensiveYards = sum(DefYards), 
    TotalWins = sum(wins)) %>% 
  mutate(
    OffensiveYPP = TotalYards/TotalPlays, 
    DefensiveYPP = DefensiveYards/DefensivePlays)


From the data, we need to only show Maryland and its yards per play.


Code
#Graph
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(
    data=years_md, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, size=TotalWins), 
    color="red") + 
  geom_vline(xintercept = 5.700174) + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 5.55143) + 
  geom_text_repel(
    data=years_md, 
    aes(x=OffensiveYPP, y=DefensiveYPP, label=Season)
  ) +
  labs(title="Offense is going right for Maryland", subtitle="Through seven games in 2023, Maryland is on the right track.", caption="Source: NCAA | By Dylan Manfre")  + theme_minimal() + 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
    )





Through seven games in 2023, Maryland is averageing a little over six yards per play on offense and so far it’s netted the program five wins. Though, some may say it should be six after a loss to Illinois on homecoming.
In the era of Mike Locksley - since 2019 - Maryland has been a bit all over the place. That 2019 season, Maryland allowed quite a bit of yardage. It was the msot out of the available data. The Terps can push that forward if they continue playing to their strengths annd not giving up yards to their opponents.

title: Third and Six
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(cfbfastR)


dataframes # load the pbp data


Code
plays <- load_cfb_pbp(seasons = c(2019, 2020, 2021, 2022, 2023))
View(plays)




Code
big10 <- c("Nebraska", "Iowa", "Minnesota", "Illinois", "Northwestern", "Wisconsin", "Indiana", "Purdue", "Ohio State", "Michigan", "Michigan State", "Penn State", "Rutgers", "Maryland")




Code
#filtering for third and six

#shows all 3,6 plays regardless of team
third_six <- plays %>% 
  filter(down == 3, distance == 6)

View(third_six)




Code
#All Teams section

#Number of play types on third and six / Number of run plays on third and six

#2359 rushing plays happened on third and six. (2459 if you include the 100 rushing touchdowns)


teams_play_type <- third_six %>%
  group_by(play_type) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
#Run play percentage on third and six
#Teamss rushed the ball 20% of the time on third and six. Third most common among the play types.

teams_play_perc <- teams_play_type %>% 
  mutate(play_perc = count/sum(count)*100)




Code
#Average yards gained on third and six runs
#Teams rushed for an average of 5.6 yards on third and six.

teams_avg_rushyds <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush") %>% 
  summarize(avg_rushyds = mean(yards_gained))


Number of third and six runs for available data 2022 had the most rushes on third and 6.


Code
yearly_rushes <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush") %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


Which team ran on third and six the most? Navy ran the most on third and six over the last four seasons with 49 times. Army was second with 42. Must be all that training.


Code
teams_rushed <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush") %>% 
  group_by(pos_team) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


Maryland Section
Counting the number of play types on third and six. Number of Runs? Maryland rushed 15 times on third and six.


Code
md_play_types <- third_six %>%
  filter(pos_team == "Maryland") %>% 
  group_by(play_type) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


Run percentage: Maryland ran the ball 27% of the time on third and six.


Code
play_perc <- md_play_types %>% 
  mutate(play_perc = count/sum(count)*100)


6.5 rushing yards per game on third and six for Maryland.


Code
md_avg_rushyds <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush" | play_type == "Rushing Touchdown", pos_team == "Maryland") %>%
  summarize(avg_rushyds = mean(yards_gained))


Yearly totals for Maryland rushing on third and six show Maryland rushed 6 times on third and six in 2022 and four times so far this year


Code
md_yearly_rushes <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush", pos_team == "Maryland") %>% 
  group_by(year) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))

third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush", pos_team == "Maryland", season == "2022") %>% 
  group_by(period) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


# A tibble: 3 × 2
  period count
   <int> <int>
1      2     2
2      3     2
3      4     2


In third and six situations, Maryland seems to have done this mostly against Big Ten teams.


Code
teams_md_rush_against <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush", pos_team == "Maryland") %>% 
  group_by(def_pos_team) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))


Has Maryland done this in the crunch time before?


Code
#Just MD
third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush", period == 4, clock.minutes < 4, pos_team == "Maryland" )

Code
#Big Ten
b10_rush_third_six <- third_six %>% 
  filter(play_type == "Rush", period == 4, clock.minutes < 4, pos_team %in% big10 )


Blog Post
After Maryland’s rather unsuccessful run on third and six against Illinois, fans questioned whether it was the right call. At the time, maybe not, but over the last four years, Maryland has called a rushing play on third and six three times against Illinois.
That’s tied for the most against a single opponent with fellow Big Ten foe Ohio State. Maryland ran the ball six times on third and six last season and they all came outside of the first quarter.
However, of the times Maryland found itself in this situation, two instances were in crunch time with under four minutes remaining in the game. The most recent was in 2022 against NC State, a game Maryland won 16-12. The play came with 42 seconds left on the clock.
For Maryland, these situations happen from time to time but to put this in context, third and six rushes happened a total of 24 times in the Big Ten from 2019 to this season in crunch time.


Code
#graph showing how much third and six rushes have happened per season.
#line chart with y axis as years and x axis as number of times it's happened.
#Can also highlight Maryland in this

b10_rush_third_six <- b10_rush_third_six %>%
  filter(!is.na(season))

b10_years <- b10_rush_third_six %>% 
  group_by(season) %>% 
  summarize(count = n()) %>% 
  arrange(desc(count))




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(
    data=b10_years, 
    aes(x=reorder(season, -`count`),
        weight=`count`)) + 
  labs(
    title="Rushing on 3rd and 6 not too uncommon in the Big Ten", 
    x="Year", 
    y="Number of plays") + 
  theme_minimal() + 
  coord_flip()
